verses.verse: Now concerning the things you wrote to me. It is good for a man not to [sexually] touch a woman.
Nevertheless because of fornication, let every man have his own wife, and let every woman have her own husband.
Let the husband give his wife the affection due her, and likewise the wife also to her husband.
The wife doesn't have authority over her own body, but the husband does, and likewise the husband also doesn't have authority over his own body, but the wife does.

Don't deprive one another except with mutual consent for a short time, so that you may give yourselves to fasting and prayer, and come together again so that Satan doesn't tempt you for your lack of self-control.
But I tell you this by permission, not from commandment.
For I wish that all men were even as I am myself, but every man has his 1Co 7:proper gift from God, one in this way and another in that way.
Therefore I say to the unmarried and widows, "It is good for them if they remain just as I am."
But if they cannot hold their desires in check, let them marry, for it is better to marry than to burn.
To the married I command, [yet] not I but the Lord, "Don't let the wife depart from her husband."
But if she does leave, let her remain unmarried or else be reconciled to her husband. And don't let the husband leave his wife.
Now concerning the rest I speak, not the Lord. If any brother has an unbelieving wife and she is pleased to live with him, let him not send her away.
And if a woman has an unbelieving husband, and if he is pleased to live with her, she should not leave him.

For the unbelieving husband is considered holy because of the wife, and the unbelieving wife is considered holy because of the husband, otherwise your children would be unclean, but now they are considered holy.
But if the unbelieving one departs, let him depart. A brother or sister is not under bondage in such cases, moreover God has called us to peace.
For how do you know, wife, whether you will save your husband, or how do you know, husband, whether you will save your wife?
But only as God distributed to each, as the Lord has called each, so let them walk.
Is any man called already circumcised? He shouldn't become uncircumcised. Is any called while uncircumcised? He shouldn't become circumcised.
Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing. The keeping of God's commands [are everything].
Every one should remain in the same calling in which he was called.
Are you called while a servant? Don't worry about it. But if you can be free, use [it] instead.
For he who is called in the Lord, while a servant, is the Lord's freeman, in the same way he, who is called, while free, is Christ's servant.
You are bought with a price; do not be the servants of men.
Brethren, let every one in which he was called, remain in it with God.
Now concerning virgins, I have no command from the Lord; yet I give my opinion as one who has obtained mercy from the Lord to be faithful.
Therefore I think it is best for this present distress that it is good for a man to be so.
Are you married to a wife? Don't seek to be separated. Are you unmarried? Don't seek a wife.
But and if you marry, you have not sinned, and if a virgin woman marries, she has not sinned. Nevertheless such will have distress in the flesh, and I want to spare you.
But I say this brethren, the time is short so from now on those that have wives be though they had none,

and those that weep as though they didn't weep, those rejoice as though they didn't rejoice, and those who that buy as though they didn't possess nothing, 1Co 7:31 and those that make use of this world as not misusing it, for the present form of this world passes away.
I want you to be without worry. He who is unmarried worries about the Lord's things, how he can please the Lord,
but he who is married does worry about the world's things, how he can please his wife.

There is difference also concerning a wife and unmarried virgin. The unmarried woman worries about the Lord's things, so that she can be holy both in body and in spirit, but she that is married worries about the things the world, how she can please her husband.

Now I say this for your own profit, not so that I can put a noose on you, instead [it is] for that which is appropriate for the circumstances and so that you may attend to the Lord without distraction.
But if any man thinks that he might misbehave towards his virgin, if she might pass her prime, and thus it must be, let him do what he wishes, he does not sin. Let them marry.
Nevertheless he who continues resolved in his heart, having no need, having control over his will, and having firmly decided in his heart that he will keep his virgin [as she is] does well.
So then he who gives [her] in marriage does well, but he who doesn't give [her] in marriage does better.
The wife is bound by the law as long as her husband lives, but if her husband is dead, she is free to be married to whom she wants but only in the Lord.
But she is happier if she remains [unmarried], in my opinion, and I think that I also have the Spirit of God.
